facts.text: The appellants are the workmen of the Dimakuchi Tea Estate represented by the Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha, Dibrugarh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants before us are the workmen of the Dimakuchi Tea Estate represented by the Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha, Dibrugarh. The respondent is the management of the Dimakuchi tea estate, district Darrang, in Assam.

facts.text: The respondent is the management of the Dimakuchi tea estate, district Darrang, in Assam.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is the management of the Dimakuchi tea estate, district Darrang, in Assam. One Dr. K. P. Banerjee was appointed assistant medical officer of the Dimakuchi tea estate with effect from November 1, 1950.

facts.text: Dr. K. P. Banerjee was appointed assistant medical officer of the Dimakuchi tea estate with effect from November 1, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: One Dr. K. P. Banerjee was appointed assistant medical officer of the Dimakuchi tea estate with effect from November 1, 1950. He was appointed subject to a satisfactory medical report and on probation for three months.

facts.text: Dr. K. P. Banerjee was appointed subject to a satisfactory medical report and on probation for three months.

anchor.surface_text: He was appointed subject to a satisfactory medical report and on probation for three months. It was stated in his letter of appointment While you are on probation or trial, your suitability for permanent employment will be companysidered.

facts.text: In February 1951 Dr. Banerjee was given increment of Rs. 5 per mensem.

anchor.surface_text: In February 1951 Dr. Banerjee was given increment of Rs. 5 per mensem, but on April 21 Dr. Banerjee received a letter from one Mr. Booth, manager of the tea estate, in which it was stated It has been found necessary to terminate your services with effect from 22nd instant.

facts.text: On April 21 Dr. Banerjee received a letter from Mr. Booth, manager, terminating services with effect from 22nd instant and one month's salary in lieu of notice.

anchor.surface_text: but on April 21 Dr. Banerjee received a letter from one Mr. Booth, manager of the tea estate, in which it was stated It has been found necessary to terminate your services with effect from 22nd instant. You will of companyrse receive one months salary in lieu of numberice.

facts.text: Manager replied that reasons for discharge are on medical side, deceitful manner in adding figures to medical indent.

anchor.surface_text: To this Dr. Banerjee received a reply to this effect The reasons for your discharge are on the medical side, which are outside my jurisdiction, best known to Dr. Cox, but a main reason is because of the deceitful manner in which you added figures to the requirements of the last medical indent after it had been signed by Dr. Cox, evidence of which is in my hands.

facts.text: Manager stated Dr. Banerjee discharged on ground of incompetence in medical duties, Dr. Cox found incompetent, faulty quinine injection to Mr. Peacock.

anchor.surface_text: The manager wrote back to say that Dr. K. P. Banerjee was discharged on the ground of incompetence in his medical duties and the chief medical officer  Dr. Cox  had found that Dr. Banerjee was incompetent and did number have sufficient knowledge of simple everyday microscopical and laboratory work which befalls the lot of every assistant medical officer in tea garden practice.

facts.text: Certain conciliation proceedings were held unsuccessfully over termination of Dr. Banerjee's service.

anchor.surface_text: The reasons given by the manager for the termination of the services of Dr. K. P. Banerjee did number satisfy the appellants herein and certain companyciliation proceedings, details whereof are number necessary for our purpose, were unsuccessfully held over the question of the termination of the service of Dr. Banerjee.

facts.text: Matter referred to tripartite Appellate Board consisting of Labour Commissioner Assam and two representatives.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was then referred to a Board known as the tripartite Appellate Board companysisting of the Labour Commissioner, Assam, and two representatives of the Assam branch of the Indian Tea Association and the Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha respectively.

facts.text: Board recommended Dr. Banerjee be reinstated with effect from date of discharge.

anchor.surface_text: This Board recommended that Dr. Banerjee should be reinstated with effect from the date of his discharge.

facts.text: Respondent offered 28 months salary and allowances in lieu of reinstatement, appellants did not agree.

anchor.surface_text: After the recommendation of the Board, the respondent herein appears to have offered a sum equal to 28 months salary and allowances in lieu of reinstatement to this, however, the appellants did number agree.

facts.text: Dr. K. P. Banerjee received Rs. 306-1-0 on May 22, 1951 and left the tea garden.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime Dr. K. P. Banerjee received a sum of Rs. 306-1-0 on May 22, 1951 and left the tea garden in question.

facts.text: On December 23, 1953, Government of Assam published notification referring dispute to Shri U.K. Gohain under s.10(1)(c) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Then, on December 23, 1953, the Government of Assam published a numberification in which it was stated that whereas an industrial dispute has arisen between the appellants and the respondent herein and whereas it was expedient that the dispute should be referred for adjudication to a Tribunal companystituted under s. 7 of the Act,

facts.text: Dispute referred: Whether management justified in dismissing Dr. K.P. Banerjee; if not, entitled to reinstatement or other relief.

anchor.surface_text: the Governor of Assam was pleased to refer the dispute to Shri U.K. Gohain. Additional District and Sessions Judge, under clause  c  of sub-s.  1  of s. 10 of the Act. The dispute which was thus referred to the Tribunal was described in these terms Whether the management of Dimakuchi Tea Estate was justified in dismissing Dr. K. P. Banerjee, A.M.O. ?

facts.text: Both parties filed written statements before Mr. Gohain.

Banerjee was number a workman within the meaning of the Act therefore, there was numberindustrial dispute in the sense in which that expression was defined in the Act and the Tribunal had numberjurisdiction to make an adjudication on merits.

facts.text: Tribunal (Mr. Gohain) held Dr. Banerjee not a workman, no industrial dispute, no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Gohain took up a preliminary point the question if Dr. Banerjee was a workman within the meaning of the Act and came to a companyclusion which may be best expressed in his own words Dr. Banerjee being number a workman, his case is number one of an industrial dispute under the Industrial Disputes Act and his case is therefore beyond the jurisdiction of this Tribunal and the Tribunal has therefore numberjurisdiction to give any relief to him.

facts.text: Appeal to Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta affirmed finding that Dr. Banerjee not a workman.

anchor.surface_text: There was then an appeal to the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta. That Tribunal affirmed the finding of Mr. Gohain to the effect that Dr. Banerjee was number a workman within the meaning of the Act.

facts.text: Appellants obtained special leave from this Court on March 14, 1956, limited to question whether dispute re non-workman falls within s.2(k).

anchor.surface_text: The appellants herein then moved this Court for special leave and by an order dated March 14, 1956, special leave was granted, but was limited to the question whether a dispute in relation to a person who is number a workman falls within the scope of the definition of industrial dispute companytained in s. 2 k  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

facts.text: Court proceeds on footing that Dr. K. P. Banerjee was not a workman within the meaning of the Act.

issues.text: the true scope and effect of the definition clause in s. 2 k of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947

anchor.surface_text: The question is the true scope and effect of the definition clause in s. 2 k  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  hereinafter referred to as the Act . The question has arisen in the following circumstances. The appellants before us are the workmen of the Dimakuchi Tea Estate

If we analyse the definition clause, it falls easily and naturally into three parts first, there must be a dispute or a difference second,

issues.text: whether a dispute in relation to a person who is not a workman, falls within the scope of the definition of Industrial Dispute contained in s. 2 k of the Act

anchor.surface_text: From that decision the present appeal by the workmen of the Tea Estate arises with leave granted by this Court under Art. 136 of the Constitution. In granting the leave this Court limited it to the question whether a dispute in relation to a person who is not a workman, falls within the scope of the definition of Industrial Dispute contained in s. 2 k  of the Act.

In the absence of such interest the dispute cannot be said to be a real dispute between the parties.

arguments.claim: A dispute between the employers and employees to be an industrial dispute within the meaning of section 2 k of the Industrial Disputes Act, must be between the employers and the workmen. There cannot be any industrial dispute between the employers and the employees who are not workmen.

anchor.surface_text: That Tribunal affirmed the finding of Mr. Gohain to the effect that Dr. Banerjee was not a workman within the meaning of the Act. The Appellate Tribunal then said A dispute between the employers and employees to be an industrial dispute within the meaning of section 2 k of the Industrial Disputes Act, must be between the employers and the workmen.

arguments.court_reasoning: SC accepts not workman but rejects equation of 'any person' strictly to workman, requires community of interest.

arguments.claim: The conditions referred to in the first and second parts of the definition clause are clearly fulfilled... the dispute or difference is between the employer... and its workmen... even taking the expression workman in the restricted sense... the expression of any person occurring in the third part... is expression of very wide import and there are no reasons why the words any person should be equated with any workman.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants it is contended that the conditions referred to in the first and second parts of the definition clause are clearly fulfilled in the present case, because there is a dispute or difference over the termination of service of Dr. K. P. Banerjee and the dispute or difference is between the employer, namely, the management of the Dimakuchi tea estate on one side, and its workmen on the other, even taking the expression workman in the restricted sense in which that expression is defined in the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: old its proceedings expeditiously and shall as soon as practicable on the companyclusion thereof submit its award to the appropriate Government. Secti

arguments.court_reasoning: Cannot mean anybody; limitations from context, scheme of Act; absurd results.

arguments.claim: Four limitations on 'any person': 1. real and substantial dispute where relief possible; 2. relate to particular establishment; 3. person must be employee discharged/in service/candidate; 4. workmen nexus via personal/general interest.

anchor.surface_text: When these difficulties were pointed out to learned counsel for the appellants, he conceded that some limitations must be put on the width of the expression any person occurring in the definition clause. He formulated four such limitations The dispute must be a real and substantial one...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: and  4  the workmen raising the dispute were vitally interested in it by reason of the fact that Dr. Banerjee  it is stated  belonged to their trade

arguments.court_reasoning: Accepts 1 and 2 implicit; rejects 3 as too wide (not any employee, but community interest); 4 too general (must be based on community interest).

arguments.claim: The expression any person cannot mean anybody and everybody... limitation that employer-employee relation possible; read in context of scheme of Act... harmonise with subject and object.

anchor.surface_text: A little careful consideration will show, however, that the expression any person occurring in the third part of the definition clause cannot mean anybody and everybody in this wide world. First of all, the subject matter of dispute must relate to i employment or non-employment or ii terms of employment or conditions of labour of any person these necessarily import a limitation in the same that a person in respect of whom the employer-employee relation never existed or can never possibly exist cannot be the subject matter of a dispute between employers and workmen.

arguments.claim: Absurd results if wide: workmen dispute over DM/DJ employment; no community interest.

anchor.surface_text: Let us assume that for some reason or other the workmen of a particular industry raise a dispute with their employer about the employment or terms of employment of the District Magistrate or District Judge of the district in which the industry is situate. It seems clear to us that though the District Magistrate or District Judge undoubtedly comes within the expression any person occurring in the definition clause, a dispute about him employment or terms of employment is not an industrial dispute firstly, because such a dispute does not come within the scope of the Act, having regard to the definition of the words employer, industry, and workman and also to other provisions of the Act secondly there is no possible community of interest between the District Magistrate or District Judge on the one hand and the disputants, employer and workmen, on the other.

arguments.claim: S.18 binding nature: award binds parties and all workmen in establishment, not the non-workman person; cannot summon non-party.

anchor.surface_text: Section 18 is important for our purpose, and in so far as it relates to awards it states that an award which has become enforceable shall be binding on - a all parties to the industrial dispute b all other parties summoned to appear in the proceedings as parties to the dispute, unless the Tribunal records the opinion that they were so summoned without proper cause c where a party referred to under clause a or clause b is an employer, his heirs, successors or assigns in respect of the establishment to which the dispute relates and d where a party referred to in clause a or clause b is composed of workmen, all persons who are employed in the establishment or part of establishment as the case may be, to which the dispute relates on the date of the dispute and all persons who subsequently become employed in that establishment or part.

arguments.claim: S.36 representation only for workmen/employers, no provision for others.

anchor.surface_text: Section 36 which deals with representation of parties has some bearing on the question before us. It lays down that a workman who is a party to a dispute shall be entitled to be represented in any proceeding under the Act by - a an officer of a registered trade union of which he is a member b an officer of a federation of trade unions to which the trade union referred to in clause a is affiliated and c where the worker is not a member of any trade union, by officer of any trade union connected with, or by any other workman employed in the industry in which the worker is employed and authorised in such manner as may be prescribed.

arguments.claim: The expression any person means a person in whose employment or non-employment... the workmen as a class have a direct or substantial interest - with whom they have... a community of interest.

anchor.surface_text: The expression any person in the definition clause means, in our opinion, a person in whose employment or non-employment or terms of employment, or conditions of labour the workmen as a class have a direct or substantial interest - with whom they have, under the scheme of the Act, a community of interest.

arguments.claim: Workmen no direct/substantial interest in supervisory staff (non-workmen); Act distinguishes and confers benefits only on workmen.

anchor.surface_text: Can it be said that workmen as a class are directly or substantially interested in the employment, non-employment, terms of employment or conditions of labour of persons who belong to the supervisory staff and are, under provisions of the Act, non-workmen on whom the Act has conferred no benefit, who cannot by themselves be parties to an industrial dispute and for whose representation the Act makes no particular provision ? We venture to think that the answer must be in the negative.

arguments.claim: In this case, Dr. Banerjee not workman, medical staff different category, appellants no direct/substantial interest.

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us, Dr. K. P. Banerjee was not a workman. He belonged to the medical or technical staff - a different category altogether from workmen. The appellants had no direct, no substantial interest in his employment or non-employment, and even assuming that he was a member of the same Trade Union, it cannot be said, on the tests laid down by us, that the dispute regarding his termination of service was an industrial dispute within the meaning of s. 2 k of the Act.

arguments.claim: Words any person have ordinary meaning including non-workman; no reason to restrict to workman class; cases support wide meaning.

anchor.surface_text: These words are quite general and very wide and according to their ordinary meaning include a person who is not a workman. If this meaning is given to these words, then the dispute that arose concerning Dr. Banerjees dismissal would be and industrial dispute because the dispute would then be clearly within s. 2 k . This indeed is not disputed. Unless there are reasons to the contrary these words have to be given their ordinary meaning.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: in this dispute ? The increase in the wages claimed companyld number in any manner improve the financial companydition of the disputing workmen, numb

arguments.court_reasoning: Majority holds limitations from context/scheme necessary.

arguments.claim: No good reasons to restrict any person; s.18(d) does not limit to future workmen; scheme does not require restriction to workman class.

anchor.surface_text: Are there then good reasons for not giving to the words any persons their plain meaning ? Several have been advanced and I shall examine them a little later... I entirely fail to see how that section assists at all in finding out who were meant to be included in the words any person.

arguments.court_reasoning: Majority applies harmonious/purposive to limit via community interest.

holdings.text: Dr. K. P. Banerjee was not a workman within the meaning of the Act

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from what has been stated above that the question whether Dr. K. P. Banerjee is or not a workman within the meaning of the Act is no longer open to the parties and we must proceed on the footing that Dr. K. P. Banerjee was not a workman within the meaning of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower tribunals unanimously held so; affirmed by Labour Appellate Tribunal; special leave limited excluding re-agitation of this issue

holdings.text: The expression any person in s. 2 k of the Act must be read subject to such limitations and qualifications as arise from the context the two crucial limitations are 1 the dispute must be a real dispute between the parties to the dispute as indicated in the first two parts of the definition clause so as to be capable of settlement or adjudication by one party to the dispute giving necessary relief to the other, and 2 the person regarding whom the dispute is raised must be one in whose employment, non-employment, terms of employment, or conditions of labour as the case may be the parties to the dispute have a direct or substantial interest

anchor.surface_text: To summarise. Having regard to the scheme and objects of the Act, and its other provisions, the expression any person in s. 2 k of the Act must be read subject to such limitations and qualifications as arise from the context the two crucial limitations are 1 the dispute must be a real dispute between the parties to the dispute  as indicated in the first two parts of the definition clause  so as to be capable of settlement or adjudication by one party to the dispute giving necessary relief to the other, and 2 the person regarding whom the dispute is raised must be one in whose employment, non-employment, terms of employment, or conditions of labour  as the case may be  the parties to the dispute have a direct or substantial interest.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction with scheme/object of Act (industrial peace between employers/workmen); s.18 binding only on parties/workmen; s.36 representation limited; absurd results from literal reading (e.g. dispute over DM/DJ); policy to benefit workmen class

holdings.text: The expression any person means a person in whose employment or non-employment or terms of employment, or conditions of labour the workmen as a class have a direct or substantial interest - with whom they have, under the scheme of the Act, a community of interest

anchor.surface_text: The expression any person in the definition clause means, in our opinion, a person in whose employment or non-employment or terms of employment, or conditions of labour the workmen as a class have a direct or substantial interest - with whom they have, under the scheme of the Act, a community of interest.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between workmen/non-workmen/supervisory staff; Act confers benefits only on workmen; requires community of interest test for real dispute

holdings.text: Workmen as a class are [not] directly or substantially interested in the employment, non-employment, terms of employment or conditions of labour of persons who belong to the supervisory staff and are, under provisions of the Act, non-workmen

anchor.surface_text: Can it be said that workmen as a class are directly or substantially interested in the employment, non-employment, terms of employment or conditions of labour of persons who belong to the supervisory staff and are, under provisions of the Act, non-workmen on whom the Act has conferred no benefit, who cannot by themselves be parties to an industrial dispute and for whose representation the Act makes no particular provision ? We venture to think that the answer must be in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supervisory/non-workmen receive no benefits under Act; cannot be parties; no representation provision; no community of interest

holdings.text: In the case before us, Dr. K. P. Banerjee was not a workman. He belonged to the medical or technical staff - a different category altogether from workmen. The appellants had no direct, no substantial interest in his employment or non-employment... the dispute regarding his termination of service was an industrial dispute within the meaning of s. 2 k of the Act

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us, Dr. K. P. Banerjee was not a workman. He belonged to the medical or technical staff - a different category altogether from workmen. The appellants had no direct, no substantial interest in his employment or non-employment, and even assuming that he was a member of the same Trade Union, it cannot be said, on the tests laid down by us, that the dispute regarding his termination of service was an industrial dispute within the meaning of s. 2 k of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dr. Banerjee medical/technical staff (different category); no direct/substantial interest despite possible union membership; fails community of interest test

holdings.text: The appeal fails and is dismissed

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that the appeal fails and is dismissed. In the circumstances of this case there will be no order for costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dispute not industrial dispute under s.2(k); lower tribunals correctly held no jurisdiction

precedents.citation: Narendra Kumar Sen v. All India Industrial Disputes  Labour Appellate  Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: Narendra Kumar Sen v. All India Industrial Disputes  Labour Appellate  Tribunal If any person were to be read as an expression without any limitation and qualification whatsoever, then we must not put even any territorial restriction on that expression.

precedents.case_name: Narendra Kumar Sen v. All India Industrial Disputes Labour Appellate Tribunal
precedents.cited_proposition: Absurd results follow if 'any person' is read without limitation, including no territorial restriction

precedents.citation: George Hudson Ltd. v. Australian Timber Workers Union 32 C.L.R. 413, 441

anchor.surface_text: George Hudson Ltd. v. Australian Timber Workers Union 32 C.L.R. 413, 441 The very nature of an industrial dispute as distinguished from an individual dispute, is to obtain new industrial conditions, not merely for the specific individuals then working from the specific individuals then employing them, and not for the moment only. But for the class of employees from the class of employers

precedents.case_name: George Hudson Ltd. v. Australian Timber Workers Union
precedents.cited_proposition: Nature of industrial dispute is collective for class of employees and employers

precedents.citation: Western India Automobile Association v. Industrial Tribunal of Bombay 1949 F.C.R. 321

anchor.surface_text: Western India Automobile Association v. Industrial Tribunal of Bombay 1949 F.C.R. 321 it was held that the words any person were not meant to refer only to workmen as defined in the Act but were wide and general and would include others who were not such workmen.

precedents.case_name: Western India Automobile Association v. Industrial Tribunal of Bombay

precedents.citation: The Dalhousie Jute Co. Ltd. v. S. N. Modak 1951 1 L.L.J. 154

anchor.surface_text: The Dalhousie Jute Co. Ltd. v. S. N. Modak 1951 1 L.L.J. 154, Banerjee J. said, Any person means whatever individual is chosen. I see no reason to restrict the meaning of the word person.

precedents.case_name: Dalhousie Jute Co. Ltd. v. S. N. Modak
precedents.cited_proposition: Any person means whatever individual without restriction

anchor.surface_text: To summarise. Having regard to the scheme and objects of the Act, and its other provisions, the expression any person in s. 2 k of the Act must be read subject to such limitations and qualifications as arise from the context the two crucial limitations are 1 the dispute must be a real dispute between the parties to the dispute  as indicated in the first two parts of the definition clause  so as to be capable of settlement or adjudication by one party to the dispute giving necessary relief to the other, and 2 the person regarding whom the dispute is raised must be one in whose employment, non-employment, terms of employment, or conditions of labour  as the case may be  the parties to the dispute have a direct or substantial interest.

edges.explanation: h2 limitations answer whether non-workman dispute within s.2(k)
h2 directly on whether non-workman dispute falls in s.2(k) definition

anchor.surface_text: The expression any person in the definition clause means, in our opinion, a person in whose employment or non-employment or terms of employment, or conditions of labour the workmen as a class have a direct or substantial interest - with whom they have, under the scheme of the Act, a community of interest.

anchor.surface_text: Can it be said that workmen as a class are directly or substantially interested in the employment, non-employment, terms of employment or conditions of labour of persons who belong to the supervisory staff and are, under provisions of the Act, non-workmen on whom the Act has conferred no benefit, who cannot by themselves be parties to an industrial dispute and for whose representation the Act makes no particular provision ? We venture to think that the answer must be in the negative.
The result, therefore, is that the appeal fails and is dismissed. In the circumstances of this case there will be no order for costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us, Dr. K. P. Banerjee was not a workman. He belonged to the medical or technical staff - a different category altogether from workmen. The appellants had no direct, no substantial interest in his employment or non-employment, and even assuming that he was a member of the same Trade Union, it cannot be said, on the tests laid down by us, that the dispute regarding his termination of service was an industrial dispute within the meaning of s. 2 k of the Act.
